instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP5V_G3H: What is PP5V_G3H? PP5V_G3H is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a G3H mechanical off state.
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.TPS62180: What is TPS62180? This is a power chip responsible for many different power rails on 2016-2020 Macbook Pros,  most often known as the SSD buck converter chip responsible for NAND power rails.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v 30mA
threads.message:
20v 30mA on all USBC

Dead machine, corrosion on <CAPACITOR>C9583</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C9584</CAPACITOR>, both replaced but <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> still 0v
<CHIP>U9580</CHIP> reflowed then lifted and refitted - no change.
Board otherwise immaculate.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.6v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3H</SIGNAL> 5.1v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLP2RSW_DFR</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 0v (not shorted)

Not seen by Apple Configurator 2 run on non T2 MacBook at possibly different MacOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v 30mA
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> still 0v"
What about diode mode to ground there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v 30mA
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v 30mA
threads.message:
Check if all AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages are present.
Be sure to follow all the steps to put the machine in DFU mode.
Also try using SWK003 pads...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v 30mA
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.2v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 0.75v
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 0.8v
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1.1v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1.8v

Tried to get DFU mode via instructions on [URL]https://logi.wiki/index.php/DFU_Mode_Restore_(Macs)[/URL] AND via momentary short of SWK003 to no effect on <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>/BigSur/AC2.
Then tried soldering perm jumper over SWK003 and success getting DFU mode

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v 30mA
threads.message: You must release the jumper, once entered into DFU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v 30mA
threads.message: I wondered. Is the idea to restore? Does this wipe customers files - as the screen message alludes to?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v 30mA
threads.message:
Restore erase the SSD.
Do Revive instead...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v 30mA
threads.message:
Revive appears to timeout with "System cannot be restored on this device - Gave up waiting for device to transition from DFU state to DFU state".

Even "Restart Device" which I consider a safe option fails with message "Configurator could not perform the requested action - Apple Controller devices do not support this action".
BTW I have never seen a successful completion by Apple Configurator previously on other boards either - have you see completion messages?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v 30mA
threads.message:
When complete, there is no message at all.
Usually get the padlock logo on AC2 machine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v 30mA
threads.message:
Can you suggest a next step?
Ive got a new <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> (<CHIP>TPS62180</CHIP> on order) as it is not outputting yet it has input powered 12.6v and enable 1.8v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v 30mA
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v 30mA
threads.message:
A new <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> now gives me a constant 2.5v on <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> :)
and I see currents ranging up to around 0.3amps before it finally reduces to 0.00 amps so I suspect its getting further along.
When connected only to screen no change in behaviour.

When I get into DFU mode, cut jumper lead and try revive it gets to step 4 of 4 with blue progress bar at 100% and after a while says what Ive always seen "Gave up waiting for device to transition from DFU state state to DFU state"

Will this board fan spin if good or am I just looking for a much increased current draw to know its working?
Do I need anything connected to the board that booting requires e.g. fingerprint switch.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> still 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v 30mA
threads.message:
Try with both charger and battery connected.
BTW, 96/140W for this board.

Do you get all G3S and SSD voltages now?
I suspect damage on SSD chips, caused by corrosion in <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 20v 30mA
threads.message: New <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> and correct PSU and board now boots. Thanks for your help
